choices.text: Substance P

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine?(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. VIP

 

Explanation

 

VIP is responsible for anterograde dilatation of the small intestine.

 

During peristalsis, segment of intestine behind the bolus contracts while segment in front of it relaxes.

 

Cholinergic neurons in the anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxes the segment of the intestine in front of the bolus.

 

Cholinergic neurons in the retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which contracts the segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Acetylcholine: Incorrect as acetylcholine is involved in the contraction of the intestinal segment behind the bolus, not in the dilatation.

 

Option C. Substance P: Incorrect because it also contributes to the contraction of the intestinal muscles behind the bolus.

 

Option D. Serotonin: Incorrect as serotonin is involved in overall motility and secretion within the gut but not specifically in anterograde dilatation as described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

VIP is crucial for the anterograde dilatation of the small intestine, promoting the relaxation of the intestinal segment ahead of the bolus during peristalsis, thereby facilitating the forward movement of intestinal contents.

questions.text: Below is the air pollution index chart for four consecutive days at the Delhi station. What is the categorization of the air quality index for November 23rd? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Severe

 

Based on the information provided in the query, the air quality index on November 23rd is measured at 407, falling under the severe category.

 

AIR QUALITY INDEX (AQI)

 

A tool used for effective communication of air quality status on a scale that is easily comprehensible. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

 

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI -

 

  1. PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  2. PM2.5 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  3. NO2 (Nitrogen dioxide)
  4. SO2 (Sulfur dioxide)
  5. CO (Carbon monoxide)
  6. 03 (Ozone/Trioxygen)
  7. NH3 (Ammonia)
  8. Pb (Lead)

 

AQl categories and the range are as follows:

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: What is the maximum period of voluntary self-admission under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 30 days

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 of India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment. The maximum duration for such voluntary admission is up to 30 days. If extended care is needed beyond this period, a fresh admission process is required.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 48 hours: Not the specified duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option B. 7 days: Not the maximum duration for voluntary self-admission.

 

Option D. 90 days: Far exceeds the duration mentioned in the act for voluntary self-admission.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Under the Mental Healthcare Act 2017 in India, a person with a mental illness can voluntarily admit themselves to a mental health establishment for a maximum period of 30 days.

 

Reference: Forensic Psychiatry in India, Interface of Indian laws and mental health, 27-28.

questions.text: A patient presents with a tender pulsatile mass as shown in the image below. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) CT angiogram

  • Cirsoid aneurysm is a rare type of vascular malformation that involves the dilation of multiple blood vessels and their adjacent tissue, resulting in a tangled mass of blood vessels resembling a "bag of worms".
  • These aneurysms are most commonly found in the scalp, face, and neck regions, but can occur in other parts of the body as well.
  • Symptoms may include visible swelling, throbbing or pulsating sensation, pain, and potential for bleeding or rupture.
  • Diagnosis of cirsoid aneurysm is typically made through imaging tests such as USG Doppler, CT, MRI, or angiography.
  • If the pulsatile mass is suspected to be a vascular lesion or aneurysm, a CT angiogram would be a suitable choice as it provides detailed visualization of the blood vessels, and can help define the anatomy and blood supply of the lesion.
  • It aids in planning therapeutic interventions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. FESS (functional endoscopic sinus surgery): FESS is a procedure used to treat chronic sinusitis and nasal polyps. It involves using an endoscope to view and remove the sinus blockages. This procedure is not relevant to the diagnosis or management of a vascular malformation like cirsoid aneurysm.

 

Option B. Needle aspiration: Needle aspiration is contraindicated in this scenario due to the risk of bleeding. Attempting to aspirate a pulsatile vascular lesion can lead to significant hemorrhage.

 

Option D. Intravenous antibiotics for 7 days: Intravenous antibiotics are typically used to treat infections. While pain and tenderness might suggest an infectious process, the presence of a pulsatile mass strongly suggests a vascular etiology, making antibiotics inappropriate as a primary intervention.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A CT angiogram is crucial for diagnosing and planning the treatment of a cirsoid aneurysm due to its detailed visualization of blood vessels.
  • Needle aspiration is contraindicated due to the risk of bleeding.

choices.text: Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero
No exchange of O2 & CO2
CO2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood
Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 remain normal

questions.text: Va/Q = infinity means? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. No exchange of O2 & CO2

 

Explanation

 

In quantitative terms, the ventilation-perfusion ratio is expressed as Va/Q. When Va (alveolar ventilation) is normal for a given alveolus and Q (blood flow) is also normal for the same alveolus, the ventilation-perfusion ratio (Va/Q) is also said to be normal.

 

  • This ratio explains the respiratory exchange when there is an imbalance between alveolar ventilation and alveolar blood flow
  • When the ventilation (Va) is zero, yet there is still perfusion (Q) of the alveolus, the Va/Q is zero.
  • When there is adequate ventilation (Va) but zero perfusion (Q), the ratio Va/Q is infinity.
  • At a ratio of either zero or infinity, there is no exchange of gases through the respiratory membrane of the affected alveoli.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Partial pressure of O2 becomes zero: Incorrect as partial pressure of O2 will be high in the alveoli but without perfusion, no exchange occurs.

 

Option C. CO2 alone equilibrates with the venous blood: Incorrect because without perfusion, there's no blood flow to equilibrate CO2 levels.

 

Option D. Partial pressure of both CO2 and O2 remain normal: Incorrect because, although the partial pressures in the ventilated alveoli might appear normal or even high for O2, without perfusion, these gases are not effectively exchanged with the blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ventilation-perfusion (Va/Q) ratio of infinity, indicative of ventilation without perfusion, results in no exchange of oxygen (O2) and carbon dioxide (CO2) due to the absence of blood flow to the ventilated alveoli. This scenario highlights the critical balance needed between air delivery to the lungs and blood flow through the pulmonary circulation for effective respiratory gas exchange.

questions.text: Area marked in the given image is supplied by which dermatome ? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. T10

 

The marked dermatome which includes the umbilicus is supplied by T10.

 

The T10 dermatome is significant because it corresponds to the umbilical region. Often, when clinicians check for sensation around the umbilicus, they are assessing the integrity of the T10 spinal nerve. This dermatome covers the region around the umbilicus, extending a bit below it.

 

Dermatomes are specific areas of skin that are supplied by sensory nerves originating from a single spinal nerve root. Each segment of the spinal cord gives rise to a pair (left and right) of spinal nerves, and each of these spinal nerves carries sensory information from a distinct region of the body to the spinal cord.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. T8: The T8 dermatome primarily covers the area just above the level of the umbilicus. If you were to draw a horizontal line around the trunk at the level of the umbilicus, this would approximate the center of the T8 dermatomal distribution.

 

Option B. T9: The T9 dermatome is situated just below the T8 level and above T10. It covers the region between the umbilicus and the midline of the abdomen, approximately at the level where the xiphoid process (the small cartilaginous extension at the lower end of the sternum) ends.

 

Option D. T11: The T11 dermatome covers an area of the anterior trunk below the T10 level but above the groin. It is positioned just before the first lumbar dermatome starts, and it sits above the inguinal ligament, which is a band running from the pubic tubercle to the anterior superior iliac spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The dermatomal distribution of the abdominal region is as follows:

questions.text: A 32-year-old male needs to be dressed in female lingerie and high heels to feel aroused and have intercourse with a female; he denies any sexual attraction towards males. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Transvestic fetishism

 

Transvestic fetishism involves the act of cross-dressing to achieve sexual arousal. In this case, the individual derives sexual excitement from wearing female clothing while engaging in sexual activity with females, which is characteristic of transvestic fetishism. He denies any attraction toward males, which further supports this diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Gender Dysphoria: Gender dysphoria involves a strong discomfort or distress with one’s assigned gender and a desire to be the opposite gender. There is no evidence in this scenario of dissatisfaction with his gender identity or discomfort with his sexual organs, ruling out gender dysphoria.

 

Option C. Homosexual orientation: Homosexual orientation refers to sexual attraction toward members of the same sex. The individual in this scenario specifically denies any sexual attraction to males, making this diagnosis inappropriate.

 

Option D. Testicular feminization: Testicular feminization, or Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome, is a genetic condition where an individual has a male karyotype (XY) but develops as a female due to insensitivity to androgens. This condition is unrelated to sexual arousal patterns or behaviors, and there is no evidence to support this diagnosis in the given context.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transvestic fetishism is characterized by sexual arousal from cross-dressing in individuals who do not have discomfort with their gender identity.

questions.text: A patient with a history of chronic alcohol use has developed confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia. Which vitamin deficiency is responsible for this presentation? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B1

 

The patient's presentation of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, along with a history of chronic alcohol use, is indicative of a deficiency in Vitamin B1 (thiamine). This clinical picture is consistent with Wernicke's Encephalopathy, a serious neurological disorder most commonly seen in individuals with chronic alcohol use. Alcohol use can lead to poor dietary intake and absorption, contributing to thiamine deficiency. Wernicke's Encephalopathy is characterized by the triad of mental confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (eye movement abnormalities).

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin): Deficiency in Vitamin B2 can lead to symptoms like skin disorders, anemia, and sore throat, but it is not typically associated with the neurological symptoms described in this scenario.

 

Option C. Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine): While Vitamin B6 deficiency can cause neurological symptoms, they are typically peripheral neuropathies or seizures, not the classic triad seen in Wernicke's Encephalopathy.

 

Option D. Vitamin C: Deficiency in Vitamin C leads to scurvy, characterized by symptoms like bleeding gums, bruising, joint pain, and poor wound healing, which are not consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with chronic alcohol use presenting with confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia, a Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency leading to Wernicke's Encephalopathy should be considered.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 277.

questions.text: The given instrument is used for: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Low air velocity

 

The instrument shown in the image is a Kata thermometer. The Kata thermometer was traditionally used to measure the cooling power of air. This measurement is based on how quickly the thermometer cools down when exposed to moving air, which directly correlates to the cooling effect of the air. However, its modern application is primarily focused on assessing low air velocity. It measures the rate of heat loss in still air, helping to determine the movement and speed of low-velocity air in environments such as controlled climates or specific laboratory conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Air pollution: The Kata thermometer is not used to measure air pollution. Air pollution measurement typically involves devices that can detect particulate matter or specific pollutants, such as gas analyzers or particle counters.

 

Option B. Air humidity: Measuring air humidity is generally done using hygrometer. Hygrometers determine the amount of moisture in the air, which is unrelated to the cooling effect or air velocity measurement.

 

Option C. Cooling power of air: Although historically correct, this option is no longer the primary use of the Kata thermometer. The instrument was used in the past for this purpose, but it has evolved to mainly assess low air velocity, making this answer outdated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kata thermometer is primarily used today to assess low air velocity.

questions.text: Following complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is most likely to have?(NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vitamin B12 deficiency

 

After complete ileal and partial jejunal resection, the patient is likely to have vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Normal gastric secretions contain a glycoprotein called intrinsic factor, secreted by the same parietal cells that secrete hydrochloric acid. Intrinsic factor must be present for adequate absorption of vitamin B12 from the ileum. That is, intrinsic factor combines with vitamin B12 in the stomach and protects it from being digested and destroyed as it passes into the small intestine. Then, when the intrinsic factor–vitamin B12 complex reaches the terminal ileum, the intrinsic factor binds with receptors on the ileal epithelial surface. This in turn makes it possible for the vitamin B12 to be absorbed

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Folic acid deficiency: Incorrect as the primary site for folate absorption is the jejunum. While partial jejunal resection could impact folate absorption, the redundancy in folate absorption along the small intestine generally compensates unless the resection is extensive.

 

Option C. Gastric ulcer: Incorrect because gastric ulcers are typically related to factors affecting the stomach lining, such as Helicobacter pylori infection or NSAID use, and are not directly caused by resections of the ileum or jejunum.

 

Option D. Constipation: Incorrect as constipation is more commonly associated with colonic function disruptions or changes in diet following gastrointestinal surgery, not specifically related to the ileum or jejunum resections which would more likely impact diarrhea due to reduced absorption capacities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The resection of the terminal ileum specifically compromises vitamin B12 absorption due to the loss of the primary site where the vitamin B12-intrinsic factor complex is absorbed. This can lead to significant clinical issues related to vitamin B12 deficiency, such as anemia and neurological disturbances, unless managed with appropriate supplementation.

 

Major Sites of Absorption of Hematopoietic Factors

 

  • Iron is absorbed in duodenum and upper jejunum
  • Folate is absorbed in jejunum
  • Vitamin B12 is absorbed in terminal Ileum

questions.text: The blood pressure of a population was tracked from childhood to adulthood. It was observed that those who had lower BP in childhood had low BP in adulthood, while those who had higher BP in childhood had high BP in adulthood. This can be best described as [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Tracking of blood pressure

 

The phenomenon described in the question is known as tracking of blood pressure. This term refers to the tendency for individuals to maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values over time. Essentially, individuals with lower blood pressure in childhood tend to have lower blood pressure in adulthood, and those with higher blood pressure in childhood tend to have higher blood pressure in adulthood.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rule of halves: This concept refers to the observation that about half of those with hypertension are aware of their condition, half of those aware are treated, and half of those treated are adequately controlled. It is not directly related to the tracking phenomenon described.

 

 

Option C. The WHO STEPwise approach: approach to surveillance (STEPS) is an internationally comparable, standardized and integrated surveillance tool through which countries can collect, analyse and disseminate core information on noncommunicable diseases (NCDs).

 

Option D. Primordial approach: Primordial prevention refers to measures taken to prevent the development of risk factors in a population, thereby reducing the overall incidence of disease. This concept is related to preventing the onset of risk factors and diseases, rather than tracking existing conditions over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tracking of blood pressure describes the observation that individuals maintain their relative position within a distribution of blood pressure values from childhood to adulthood. This means that blood pressure levels tend to remain consistent relative to peers over time.

questions.text: During examination of a patient with an intern, the professor asks the patient to invert his foot and he points at the prominent tendon behind the medial malleolus. Which is the tendon being pointed at here? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tibialis posterior

 

The tendon behind the medial malleolus that becomes prominent when the foot is inverted is the tibialis posterior tendon. This tendon plays a key role in foot inversion and is located just behind the medial malleolus, making it palpable during this maneuver. It functions to support the arch of the foot and assists in the inversion of the foot, which matches the scenario described in the question.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tibialis anterior: This tendon is located on the front of the ankle and is responsible for dorsiflexion and inversion of the foot but is not located behind the medial malleolus. Hence, it is not the tendon being pointed at in this scenario.

 

Option C. Extensor digitorum: This tendon is responsible for extending the toes and dorsiflexing the foot. It is located on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent during inversion.

 

Option D. Extensor hallucis longus: This tendon is involved in extending the big toe and dorsiflexing the foot. It is positioned on the dorsum of the foot, not behind the medial malleolus, and does not become prominent with foot inversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tibialis posterior tendon is located behind the medial malleolus and is most prominent when the foot is inverted. This anatomical detail is essential for identifying the tendon during a physical examination.

choices.text: Wait until TB culture results to start ATT

questions.text: A 35-year-old homeless man presented with a 1-month history of fever, cough, and weight loss. Both sputum smears turned out to be negative, but the chest x-ray ordered was suggestive of tuberculosis. According to the recent NTEP guidelines, which is the next best line of management? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Ask for CBNAAT

 

According to the National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP) guidelines, the next step in managing a patient with a high clinical suspicion of tuberculosis (TB), a suggestive chest x-ray, and negative sputum smears is to perform a CBNAAT (Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test). CBNAAT is a molecular test that detects the DNA of Mycobacterium tuberculosis and can also identify rifampicin resistance, providing rapid and accurate results.

 

DIAGNOSTIC TESTS UNDER NTEP:

 

1. Sputum smear Microscopy

  • ZN staining
  • LED – FM

 

2. Culture

 

  • LJ Medium
  • Automated Liquid culture (ALC)
    •  BACTEC MGIT 960
    • BACTALERT
    • VERSATREK

 

3. Drug sensitivity testing

 

  • Moderate Proportionate Sensitivity testing PST MGiT 960
  • Economic proportionate sensitivity testing 1% LJ Medium

 

4. Molecular Diagnosis test:

  • Line Probe Assay
    • LPA TB
    • PL LPA– INH & Rifampicin Resistance
    • SL LPA-FQ / SLI Resistance
    • NAAT
    • CBNAAT
    • True NAT True NAT
  • Developed by ICMR Real time PCR Technology 
    • True NAT MTB- MTB
    • True NAT MTB plus- MTB
    • True NAT MTB Dx- Rifampicin Resistance TEP:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Repeat sputum smears: Is not appropriate since the patient already had two negative sputum smears and a chest x-ray suggestive of tuberculosis.

 

Option C. CBNAAT: Should be performed first than Line probe assay.

 

Option D. TB: Culture takes time to yield results, the patient may deteriorate in the meantime.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Confusion assessment test is used in:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (often referred to as CAM) is a diagnostic tool specifically designed to identify delirium.

 

CAM is used primarily for the detection of delirium, especially in hospitalized or elderly patients. It evaluates features like acute onset and fluctuating course, inattention, disorganized thinking, and altered level of consciousness.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Dementia: While CAM can help differentiate delirium from dementia, it is not specifically designed for the diagnosis of dementia.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of schizophrenia.

 

Option D. Depression: CAM is not used in the diagnosis or assessment of depression.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The Confusion Assessment Method (CAM) is a tool specifically developed to detect delirium. Bedside examinations such as mini mental status examination (MMSE) are used to provide a measure of cognitive impairment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 701.

questions.text: Which of the following structures prevents the upward extension of thyroid swelling through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sternothyroid

 

  • Sternothyroid and sternohyoid muscles attach to the thyroid cartilage and can help prevent the upward extension of thyroid swelling.
  • The apex of thyroid gland is directed laterally to the oblique line of thryroid catilage where it is limited above by the attachment of sternothyroid muscle.
  • The sternohyoid muscle, which arises from the posterior surface of the manubrium and the medial end of the clavicle, also inserts onto the thyroid cartilage and can help anchor the gland in place.
  • Together, the attachment of these muscles to the thyroid cartilage can help prevent the gland from pushing upward and causing compression of adjacent structures in the neck.

 

 

  • The thyroid gland is surrounded by the pretracheal fascia, which is connected to the larynx and enables the thyroid to move during swallowing.
  • The thyrohyoid membrane, a fibrous ligament, attaches to the top of the thyroid cartilage and the hyoid bone, facilitating the upward movement of the larynx during swallowing.
  • The ligament of Berry, also known as the suspensory ligament, extends from the cricoid cartilage to the thyroid gland, preventing it from descending into the mediastinum.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pretracheal fascia: The pretracheal fascia encloses the thyroid gland, trachea, and associated structures. It anchors the thyroid gland to the trachea, ensuring that the gland moves up and down with swallowing. However, it does not prevent the upward extension of a thyroid swelling specifically through its attachment to the thyroid cartilage.

 

Option C. Thyrohyoid membrane: It is a broad, fibrous sheet that connects the thyroid cartilage (of the larynx) to the hyoid bone. It contains the superior laryngeal vessels and the internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. While it's a strong structure, its primary role is not to prevent the upward extension of thyroid swellings.

 

Option D. Ligament of Berry: It is a band of fibrous tissue that connects the thyroid gland's posterior aspect to the cricoid cartilage and the first two tracheal rings. This ligament is a key anatomical structure that serves to limit the superior (upward) movement of the thyroid gland. When performing thyroid surgeries, the ligament of Berry is a crucial landmark as it is located near the recurrent laryngeal nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sternothyroid muscle originates from the posterior surface of the manubrium of the sternum and inserts into the oblique line of the thyroid cartilage. It functions to depress the thyroid cartilage.

questions.text: A 30-week primigravida c/o reduced vision at night. She has been avoiding papaya, mango, and other fruits throughout her pregnancy as she thinks they could be abortifacients. It is the primary duty of which of the following workers to provide counselling and information to the patient? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) AWW

 

The described scenario involves a pregnant woman with a misconception about the consumption of certain fruits during pregnancy and a symptom of night blindness, which could indicate a deficiency in Vitamin A. The Anganwadi Worker (AWW) is primarily responsible for providing health and nutrition education and counselling to mothers, which includes information about proper dietary practices during pregnancy. AWWs are trained to address specific local challenges that prevent healthy behaviors, such as cultural practices, myths, local food availability, and dietary practices.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ANM (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife): ANMs primarily focus on providing basic medical care, immunizations, and assisting with childbirth and antenatal care. While they do offer some nutritional advice, the specific role of counselling about dietary misconceptions primarily falls under the AWW.

 

Option C. Trained birth attendant: Trained birth attendants are primarily involved in assisting with childbirth and ensuring safe delivery practices. Their role does not typically include extensive nutritional counselling.

 

Option D. ASHA (Accredited Social Health Activist): ASHAs work to promote community health and link the community with health services. They play a supportive role in health education, but detailed nutritional counselling is more specifically the responsibility of the AWW.

 

Educational Objective:

 

It is the duty of the Anganwadi Worker (AWW) to provide health and nutrition education and counselling to pregnant women, addressing misconceptions about diet and ensuring they receive proper nutritional guidance. Their training includes addressing local challenges and cultural practices to promote healthy behaviors.

questions.text: A patient presents with a swelling in the groin region. A diagnosis of direct inguinal hernia is made. Weakness in which of the following structures is most likely to cause this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Conjoint tendon

 

  • A direct inguinal hernia occurs when abdominal contents herniate through a weak point in the fascia of the abdominal wall.
  • This type of hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach's triangle, which is defined by the rectus abdominis muscle medially, the inferior epigastric vessels laterally, and the inguinal ligament inferiorly.
  • The conjoint tendon, which is formed by the merging of the transversus abdominis and internal oblique muscles, makes up the main part of the medial portion of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  • Weakness in the conjoint tendon is most likely to cause a direct inguinal hernia.

 

Direct Inguinal Hernia

 

  • Pathophysiology: Arises from Hesselbach’s triangle, medial to the inferior epigastric artery.
  • Mechanism: Due to weakness in the conjoint tendon.
  • Key Feature: Protrudes directly through the abdominal wall without passing through the inguinal canal.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pectineal ligament: The pectineal ligament (Cooper's ligament) is a thickened band of periosteum along the pectineal line of the pubis. It is not typically involved in the development of direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option C. Reflected part of inguinal ligament: The reflected part of the inguinal ligament is a part of the external oblique aponeurosis and is not the primary structure associated with the weakness leading to direct inguinal hernias.

 

Option D. Lacunar ligament: The lacunar ligament forms the medial boundary of the femoral canal and is associated more with femoral hernias rather than inguinal hernias.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Direct inguinal hernias result from a weakness in the conjoint tendon, which forms a crucial part of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal.
  •  This anatomical weakness allows abdominal contents to protrude directly through the abdominal wall within Hesselbach’s triangle.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presented with overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mania

 

The patient's symptoms of overfamiliarity, flight of ideas, elevated mood, increased sexual desire, and pseudo hallucination are indicative of a manic episode. Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypomania: Similar to mania but the symptoms are milder, last for at least 4 days, and don't significantly impair social or occupational functioning.

 

Option C. Cyclothymia: A mood disorder characterized by periods of hypomanic symptoms and periods of depressive symptoms that don't meet the full criteria for a manic or major depressive episode.

 

Option D. Schizomania: This term is not standard in psychiatric diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Mania is characterized by an elevated, expansive, or irritable mood, lasting at least one week, associated with increased energy or activity, and causing significant impairment in social or occupational functioning.

 

Reference: Kaplan and Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 365

questions.text: Observe the image below showing different food items. Identify the source of Thiamine. [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) B (Rice)

 

Thiamine, also known as Vitamin B1, is an essential nutrient that plays a crucial role in carbohydrate metabolism and the proper functioning of the nervous system. The primary dietary sources of thiamine are whole cereal grains, meat, and fish. In the context of the image provided, the food item labeled "B" corresponds to rice, which is a significant source of thiamine.

 

Rice, particularly unpolished or whole rice, contains a high level of thiamine in its outer layer. However, polished rice, commonly consumed in many parts of the world, loses much of its thiamine content due to the removal of the outer layer during polishing. This loss is a contributing factor to thiamine deficiency in populations that primarily consume polished rice, leading to conditions such as beriberi and Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, especially among chronic alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  Cucumber and onion: These items are not significant sources of thiamine. Vegetables like cucumbers and onions contain very low levels of thiamine and are not considered a primary dietary source of this vitamin.

 

Option C. Chapati/Flatbread: Chapatis are made from wheat flour, which does contain some thiamine. However, it is not as significant a source as rice, particularly in the whole grain form.

 

Option D. Dal/Lentil Curry: While lentils do contain some thiamine, they are not considered a primary source compared to whole grains like rice. The thiamine content in legumes is present but not in quantities significant enough to be considered the best option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rice, especially in its whole or unpolished form, is a significant dietary source of thiamine (Vitamin B1).

 

Other sources – Whole cereal, meat, fish, legumes, ground nut.

questions.text: All of the following structure pass through the aortic opening of diaphragm except? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vagal trunk

 

The vagal trunk does not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm.

 

It passes through the esophageal opening at the level of T10 vertebra.

 

The vagal trunks refer to the vagus nerves, specifically the right and left vagus nerves (cranial nerves X). These nerves are responsible for various functions in the body, including regulating heart rate, gastrointestinal activity, and respiratory functions. While the vagus nerves do extend into the thoracic cavity, they do not pass through the aortic opening of the diaphragm. Instead, they enter the abdomen separately.

 

 

 

The aortic opening of the diaphragm is an anatomical structure that allows certain structures to pass between the thoracic and abdominal cavities.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aorta: It passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm as it descends from the thoracic cavity (descending aorta) into the abdominal cavity (abdominal aorta). This is a significant passage, as it allows the aorta to continue its course into the abdomen.

 

Option B. Azygous Vein: It drains blood from the posterior thoracic and abdominal walls. It ascends through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the superior vena cava. This allows for the return of blood from the posterior part of the body to the superior vena cava and then into the right atrium of the heart.

 

Option C. Thoracic Duct: It is responsible for draining lymph from the lower half of the body and the left upper half of the body. It also passes through the aortic opening of the diaphragm to enter the thoracic cavity and eventually drain into the venous circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A male patient who was diagnosed with tuberculosis has successfully completed the full course of treatment. Subsequent to finishing both the intensive and continuation phases, the initial sputum examination was conducted. The results of this examination were negative. What is the current condition of the patient? [NEET PG 2022]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Cured

 

A patient with negative sputum examination at the end of tuberculosis treatment indicates that the patient has been cured of the disease.

 

Tuberculosis is an infectious disease caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis that primarily affects the lungs and causes pulmonary tuberculosis.

 

  • A TB case can be confirmed by positive results on smear microscopy and culture of biological specimens or diagnosed clinically by a clinician who prescribes a full course of TB treatment.
  • TB treatment consists of two phases: the intensive phase lasting for two months and the continuation phase lasting for four months.
  • Treatment involves four drugs in the intensive phase, namely isoniazid, rifampicin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol, and isoniazid along with rifampicin and ethambutol in the continuation phase.
  • After completion of treatment, the patient's sputum/culture is tested and assigned one of the following outcomes: cured, treatment completed, treatment failed, lost to follow-up, died, or not evaluated, depending on the results of the test and the patient's medical history.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Treatment Completed: Refers to a patient who has completed treatment without evidence of failure but lacks documented negative sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion.

 

Option C. Lost to Follow-Up: Refers to a patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for two consecutive months or more.

 

Option D. Treatment Failed: Refers to a patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after 5 months or more of treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Terminologies:

 

  • Cured - A TB patient whose smear or culture turned negative in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion
  • Treatment completed - A TB patient who completed treatment without any failure, but has no record to show that sputum smear or culture results in the last month of treatment and on at least one previous occasion were negative; it may be either because tests were not done or because results are unavailable
  • Treatment failed - A TB patient whose sputum smear or culture is still positive after treatment for 5 months or more
  • Lost to follow-up - A TB patient who did not start treatment or whose treatment was interrupted for 2 consecutive months or more
  • Died - A TB patient who dies before starting or during the course of treatment for any reason
  • Not evaluated - A TB patient for whom no treatment outcome is assigned; this includes cases "transferred out" to another treatment unit and cases for whom the treatment outcome is unknown to the reporting unit whose treatment is interrupted

questions.text: An employee who has been diagnosed with tuberculosis is eligible for an extended sickness benefit for? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 2 years

 

Under the Employees' State Insurance (ESI) Act of 1948, employees who are diagnosed with specific long-term illnesses, including tuberculosis, are eligible for an extended sickness benefit. This benefit provides financial support to cover a significant portion of their wages during prolonged periods of illness. The extended sickness benefit offers 80% of the employee's wages for up to 2 years. This provision ensures that employees have continued financial support while they are unable to work due to their medical condition.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: In Demographic cycle, B curve represents: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Death rate

 

In the demographic cycle, the B curve represents the death rate (Crude Death Rate - CDR). The demographic cycle is divided into five stages, which are primarily determined by birth and death rates:

 

  1. Stage 1 (High Stationary): Both the birth rate (A) and the death rate (B) are high, resulting in a stable population.
  2. Stage 2 (Early Expanding): The birth rate (A) remains high while the death rate (B) starts to decline due to improved medical facilities, causing the population to increase.
  3. Stage 3 (Late Expanding): Both birth and death rates start declining, often due to the introduction of family planning and other socio-economic factors. India is currently in this stage.
  4. Stage 4 (Low Stationary): Both rates decline to a low level, stabilizing the population growth.
  5. Stage 5 (Declining): The birth rate drops below the death rate, leading to a reduction in population size.

 

In this context, Curve B clearly represents the death rate as it follows the pattern of decline in stages 2 and 3, stabilizes in stage 4, and may increase slightly in stage 5.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Birth rate: Incorrect. Curve A represents the birth rate (Crude Birth Rate - CBR), which remains high initially but starts to decline from stage 3 onwards.

 

Option C. Growth rate: Incorrect. Growth rate is not directly shown on the graph; it is inferred from the difference between birth and death rates.

 

Option D. Total population: Incorrect. Curve C represents the total population, which increases as the death rate declines and stabilizes when both rates are low.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The B curve in the demographic cycle represents the death rate, which declines significantly from stage 2 due to improved healthcare and stabilizes in later stages.

choices.text: Esophageal veins and left gastric veins
Left colic vein and middle colic veins

questions.text: A 50-year-old male with chronic liver disease presents with abdominal pain, jaundice, and signs of portal hypertension. Which of the following venous anastomoses is most likely responsible for this condition? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Esophageal veins and left gastric veins

 

In the given scenario of a patient with portal hypertension, anastomosis between esophageal veins and left gastric veins can be seen.

 

In portal hypertension, increased pressure within the portal venous system may result in the dilation of portal venous tributaries and reversed flow at sites of portosystemic anastomoses.

 

The patient's presentation of abdominal pain, jaundice, and portal hypertension suggests an obstruction of the portal venous system, leading to the formation of portosystemic anastomoses. These are communications between the portal venous system and systemic venous system, which allow blood from the abdominal organs to bypass the liver and flow directly into the systemic circulation.

 

The lower esophageal veins, which drain into the systemic circulation via the azygos system, can anastomose with the left gastric veins (which are part of the portal system). In the context of portal hypertension, such as from cirrhosis, the blood flow through this anastomosis increases, leading to the formation of esophageal varices. These are dilated veins in the esophagus and are at risk of rupture, which can result in significant and potentially fatal bleeding.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Left colic vein and middle colic veins:  Both these veins are tributaries of the inferior mesenteric vein and subsequently drain into the portal system. They do not form a portosystemic anastomosis.

 

  • Clinical Importance: These veins aren't directly associated with the complications of portal hypertension.

 

Option C. Superior rectal and phrenic veins:  The superior rectal veins are branches of the inferior mesenteric vein and drain into the portal system, while the phrenic veins are systemic veins. However, these two veins do not directly anastomose.

 

  • Clinical Importance: They do not play a significant role in the portosystemic shunting seen in portal hypertension.

 

Option D. Sigmoid and superior rectal veins: The sigmoid veins and superior rectal veins both drain into the inferior mesenteric vein, which is a part of the portal system. They do not form a portosystemic anastomosis.

 

  • Clinical Importance: They do not contribute significantly to the clinical features of portal hypertension.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Common sites of Porto-systemic anastomoses and their clinical presentations are as follows:

questions.text: During the clinical examination of the nervous system, which of the following nerves can be tested by touching the highlighted structure? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. IX

 

The structure marked is uvula. The sensory supply to the uvula is by the glossopharyngeal nerve and it is tested in this case.

 

Motor supply to the Uvula is by vagus nerve and sensory supply by Glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Since touch is sensory activity hence the answer is sensory nerve CN IX in this case.

 

If the movement is stressed in question then motor nerve (CN X) will be the answer

 

Cranial Nerve IX (Glossopharyngeal Nerve) innervates -

 

Sensory: Supplies sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, oropharynx, and part of the ear canal. It also has a role in taste for the posterior third of the tongue.

 

Motor: Supplies the stylopharyngeus muscle.

 

Parasympathetic: Involved in salivation via the parotid gland.

 

Clinical Examination: Sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue can be tested using a cotton swab. The gag reflex can also be used to test the glossopharyngeal nerve where the gag reflex is triggered by touching the back of the throat or as the nerve innervates the uvula, touching it could also elicit a response, verifying the integrity of the nerve.

 

Pharyngeal plexus:

 

The nerve supply to the pharynx is primarily provided by the pharyngeal plexus. The pharyngeal branches of the glossopharyngeal nerve and the vagus nerve combine to form it. It also receives input from the superior cervical ganglion. The motor supply is provided by the vagus nerve, and the sensory supply is provided by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cranial Nerve X (Vagus Nerve): It gives innervations

 

  • Sensory: Provides sensation to parts of the ear canal and the pharynx. It also has visceral sensory functions for the heart, lungs, and abdominal organs.
  • Motor: Supplies muscles of the larynx, pharynx, and soft palate. It's also responsible for the "cough reflex."
  • Parasympathetic: Supplies the heart, lungs, and digestive tract up to the splenic flexure of the colon.
    • Clinical Examination: The gag reflex is a common method to test the vagus nerve (motor component) since it's responsible for the upward movement of the palate or Examining the uvula when saying "ahh" to see if it deviates (it should stay midline).

 

Option C. Cranial Nerve XI (Accessory Nerve): Supplies the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles.

 

  • Clinical Examination: Patients are asked to turn their head against resistance to test the sternocleidomastoid or Patients are asked to shrug their shoulders against resistance to test the trapezius.

 

Option D. Cranial Nerve XII (Hypoglossal Nerve): Supplies the intrinsic and extrinsic muscles of the tongue.

 

  • Clinical Examination: The patient is asked to protrude their tongue. If the nerve is damaged, the tongue will deviate to the side of the lesion.
